seg-source.mrk: Enabling and disabling JMX

target.mrk: Enabling and disabling JMX

trans-unit.source: You can use JMX management and monitoring both locally and remotely.

seg-source.mrk: You can use JMX management and monitoring both locally and remotely.

target.mrk: You can use JMX management and monitoring both locally and remotely.

seg-source.mrk: Java Management Extensions (JMX) technology

target.mrk: Java Management Extensions (JMX) technology

seg-source.mrk: JMX

target.mrk: JMX

seg-source.mrk: enabling and disabling

target.mrk: enabling and disabling

trans-unit.source: The term local means on the same host (machine) and running as the same user. For example, this means that local JMX access is possible only if the JVM you want to access is running on the same host and as the same user as the user who is running a JMX client such as JConsole (or a different user with sufficient file system permissions). In order to allow other users to access the JVM, or to allow access from other hosts, remote JMX must be enabled.

seg-source.mrk: The term local means on the same host (machine) and running as the same user.

For example, this means that local JMX access is possible only if the JVM you want to access is running on the same host and as the same user as the user who is running a JMX client such as JConsole (or a different user with sufficient file system permissions).
In order to allow other users to access the JVM, or to allow access from other hosts, remote JMX must be enabled.

target.mrk: The term local means on the same host (machine) and running as the same user.

For example, this means that local JMX access is possible only if the JVM you want to access is running on the same host and as the same user as the user who is running a JMX client such as JConsole (or a different user with sufficient file system permissions).
In order to allow other users to access the JVM, or to allow access from other hosts, remote JMX must be enabled.

seg-source.mrk: Local JMX access

target.mrk: Local JMX access

trans-unit.source: If you are using a Java SE 6 or later JVM, local JMX management and monitoring are most likely enabled by default.

seg-source.mrk: If you are using a Java SE 6 or later JVM, local JMX management and monitoring are most likely enabled by default.

target.mrk: If you are using a Java SE 6 or later JVM, local JMX management and monitoring are most likely enabled by default.

trans-unit.source: Some JVMs, for example Java SE 5 JVMs, do not enable local JMX management by default. Refer to the documentation for your JVM for details. A common way to enable local JMX access on these JVMs is to include the <codeph>-Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote</codeph> option on the command line when you start the JVM.

seg-source.mrk: Some JVMs, for example Java SE 5 JVMs, do not enable local JMX management by default.
Refer to the documentation for your JVM for details.
A common way to enable local JMX access on these JVMs is to include the <codeph>-Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote</codeph> option on the command line when you start the JVM.

target.mrk: Some JVMs, for example Java SE 5 JVMs, do not enable local JMX management by default.
Refer to the documentation for your JVM for details.
A common way to enable local JMX access on these JVMs is to include the <codeph>-Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote</codeph> option on the command line when you start the JVM.

seg-source.mrk: Remote JMX access

target.mrk: Remote JMX access

trans-unit.source: Remote JMX management and monitoring is a powerful Java feature, allowing you to monitor a specific JVM from a remote location. Enabling remote JMX requires explicit actions by the JVM administrator, since it may involve exposing sensitive information about your system.

seg-source.mrk: Remote JMX management and monitoring is a powerful Java feature, allowing you to monitor a specific JVM from a remote location.
Enabling remote JMX requires explicit actions by the JVM administrator, since it may involve exposing sensitive information about your system.

target.mrk: Remote JMX management and monitoring is a powerful Java feature, allowing you to monitor a specific JVM from a remote location.
Enabling remote JMX requires explicit actions by the JVM administrator, since it may involve exposing sensitive information about your system.

trans-unit.source: The most common way to enable remote JMX access to your JVM is to specify a TCP/IP port number and some basic security settings when you start the JVM. The security settings commonly include authentication and SSL (Secure Socket Layer). <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> attempts to use the JVM's built-in platform MBean server. For a list of current command line options (system properties) and their meanings, refer to the table in the <cite>Java SE Monitoring and Management Guide</cite> at <xref format="html" href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/management/agent.html#gdeum" scope="external">http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/management/agent.html#gdeum </xref>.

seg-source.mrk: The most common way to enable remote JMX access to your JVM is to specify a TCP/IP port number and some basic security settings when you start the JVM.
The security settings commonly include authentication and SSL (Secure Socket Layer).
<ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> attempts to use the JVM's built-in platform MBean server.

For a list of current command line options (system properties) and their meanings, refer to the table in the <cite>Java SE Monitoring and Management Guide</cite> at <xref format="html" href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/management/agent.html#gdeum" scope="external">http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/management/agent.html#gdeum </xref>.

target.mrk: The most common way to enable remote JMX access to your JVM is to specify a TCP/IP port number and some basic security settings when you start the JVM.
The security settings commonly include authentication and SSL (Secure Socket Layer).
<ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> attempts to use the JVM's built-in platform MBean server.

For a list of current command line options (system properties) and their meanings, refer to the table in the <cite>Java SE Monitoring and Management Guide</cite> at <xref format="html" href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/management/agent.html#gdeum" scope="external">http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/management/agent.html#gdeum </xref>.

trans-unit.source: The following topics describe ways to enable and disable remote JMX access.
